1.title: Romeo and Juliet
1.author: William Shakespeare
1.description:
In Romeo and Juliet, Shakespeare creates a violent world, in which two young people fall in love. It is not simply that their families disapprove; the Montagues and the Capulets are engaged in a blood feud.

In this death-filled setting, the movement from love at first sight to the lovers’ final union in death seems almost inevitable. And yet, this play set in an extraordinary world has become the quintessential story of young love. In part because of its exquisite language, it is easy to respond as if it were about all young lovers.

2.author: George Orwell
2.description: 1984 is a chilling portrayal of a totalitarian regime that uses surveillance, censorship, and mind control to maintain power. Winston Smith, the protagonist, tries to defy the oppressive government led by Big Brother, but he soon discovers that resistance is futile in a world where reality is shaped by those in control.

3.title: To Kill a Mockingbird
3.author: Harper Lee
3.description: Set in the racially segregated Southern United States during the 1930s, this novel tells the story of Scout Finch, a young girl whose father, lawyer Atticus Finch, defends a black man falsely accused of raping a white woman. This novel addresses themes of prejudice, morality, and justice.

4.title: The Catcher in the Rye
4.author: J.D. Salinger
4.description: Holden Caulfield, a disillusioned teenager, narrates his experiences after being expelled from an elite prep school. As he wanders New York City, Holden grapples with depression, alienation, and the loss of innocence, offering a poignant reflection on adolescence and society.

5.title: Moby-Dick
5.author: Herman Melville
5.description: Moby-Dick tells the story of Captain Ahab’s obsessive quest to kill the giant white whale, Moby Dick, that severed his leg. The novel explores themes of obsession, fate, and the human condition, set against the backdrop of a whaling voyage.

6.title: Pride and Prejudice
6.author: Jane Austen
6.description: This beloved novel follows the lives of the Bennet family, particularly Elizabeth Bennet, as she navigates societal expectations, family dynamics, and her evolving relationship with the proud Mr. Darcy. It offers biting commentary on class, marriage, and social standing.

7.title: The Great Gatsby
7.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
7.description: The Great Gatsby explores the Jazz Age's extravagant lifestyle and the pursuit of the American Dream through the eyes of narrator Nick Carraway, who witnesses the rise and fall of Jay Gatsby, a man obsessed with rekindling a past romance with Daisy Buchanan.

8.title: Brave New World
8.author: Aldous Huxley
8.description: In a future world where humans are genetically engineered and society is shaped by pleasure and consumption, Bernard Marx struggles with his dissatisfaction and alienation. The novel explores themes of technology, conformity, and individual freedom.

9.title: Frankenstein
9.author: Mary Shelley
9.description: Frankenstein tells the tale of Victor Frankenstein, a scientist who creates a creature in a horrific experiment. The novel explores themes of creation, responsibility, and the consequences of scientific ambition, and is often seen as a cautionary tale about unchecked progress.

10.title: The Hobbit
10.author: J.R.R. Tolkien
10.description: Bilbo Baggins, a hobbit, embarks on a perilous journey with a group of dwarves to reclaim their home from the dragon Smaug. Along the way, Bilbo encounters trolls, goblins, and elves, while discovering his own bravery and resourcefulness.

11.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
11.author: Oscar Wilde
11.description: Dorian Gray, a handsome young man, remains eternally youthful while his portrait ages, reflecting the moral decay of his character. This novel critiques vanity, hedonism, and the pursuit of beauty, and is one of Wilde's most enduring works.

12.title: The Odyssey
12.author: Homer
12.description: The Odyssey follows the adventures of Odysseus as he struggles to return home after the Trojan War. Along the way, he faces monsters, gods, and temptations, while his wife Penelope waits for his return. The epic explores themes of perseverance, loyalty, and fate.

13.title: The Road
13.author: Cormac McCarthy
13.description: A father and his young son journey through a bleak, post-apocalyptic landscape, struggling to survive against both the environment and other survivors. The novel explores love, survival, and the human spirit in a world where hope is scarce.

14.title: Catch-22
14.author: Joseph Heller
14.description: Catch-22 is a satirical novel that critiques the absurdities of war. The protagonist, Yossarian, a U.S. Army Air Forces bombardier, tries to escape the insanity of war and the contradictory rule of 'Catch-22' that ensures his doomed fate.

15.title: The Bell Jar
15.author: Sylvia Plath
15.description: The Bell Jar follows Esther Greenwood, a young woman whose life unravels as she grapples with depression, societal expectations, and her own ambitions. The novel explores themes of identity, mental illness, and the struggle for autonomy.

16.title: The Shining
16.author: Stephen King
16.description: Jack Torrance takes a job as the winter caretaker of the Overlook Hotel, where he begins to unravel due to isolation and the influence of a malevolent supernatural force. The novel explores themes of madness, family, and the supernatural.

17.title: The Secret Garden
17.author: Frances Hodgson Burnett
17.description: After the death of her parents, Mary Lennox is sent to live with her uncle in a gloomy mansion. There, she discovers a hidden garden that becomes a place of healing and transformation for both herself and others.

18.title: The Hunger Games
18.author: Suzanne Collins
18.description: In a future society, Katniss Everdeen must compete in a televised gladiatorial contest where only one person can survive. The novel critiques social inequality, the media, and the violence of survival, while exploring themes of resistance and sacrifice.

19.title: Little Women
19.author: Louisa May Alcott
19.description: The novel follows the lives of the four March sisters—Jo, Meg, Beth, and Amy—as they navigate growing up, personal struggles, and familial bonds during the American Civil War. Themes of love, sacrifice, and individuality shine through.

20.title: The Chronicles of Narnia
20.author: C.S. Lewis
20.description: The Chronicles of Narnia is a series of seven fantasy novels set in the magical land of Narnia, where talking animals, mythical creatures, and adventure await. The series explores good versus evil, faith, and personal growth.

21.title: The Kite Runner
21.author: Khaled Hosseini
21.description: The Kite Runner follows the story of Amir, a young boy from Kabul, and his complex relationship with his friend Hassan, set against the backdrop of political turmoil and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan.

22.title: The Alchemist
22.author: Paulo Coelho
22.description: The Alchemist tells the story of Santiago, a young shepherd who embarks on a journey in search of treasure. Along the way, he learns valuable life lessons about following one's dreams and the importance of listening to one's heart.

23.title: The Girl on the Train
23.author: Paula Hawkins
23.description: Rachel, an alcoholic woman, becomes obsessed with a couple she watches from the train each day. When the woman goes missing, Rachel is drawn into the investigation, leading to twists and revelations about her own past.

24.title: The Outsiders
24.author: S.E. Hinton
24.description: The Outsiders is a story about two rival teenage gangs, the Greasers and the Socs, and the struggles they face in a divided society. Themes of friendship, identity, and social inequality are explored.

25.title: Wuthering Heights
25.author: Emily Brontë
25.description: Wuthering Heights tells the tragic story of Heathcliff and Catherine Earnshaw, whose passionate and destructive love impacts not only their lives but the lives of future generations. It is a haunting exploration of love, vengeance, and obsession.

26.title: A Game of Thrones
26.author: George R.R. Martin
26.description: A Game of Thrones is the first book in the epic series 'A Song of Ice and Fire,' which follows the political and military struggles of various noble houses in the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros. It is known for its complex characters, power struggles, and brutal betrayals.

27.title: The Handmaid's Tale
27.author: Margaret Atwood
27.description: Set in a totalitarian society, The Handmaid's Tale tells the story of Offred, a woman forced into reproductive servitude in a world where women’s rights have been stripped away. It explores themes of power, gender, and resistance.

28.title: The Grapes of Wrath
28.author: John Steinbeck
28.description: The Grapes of Wrath follows the Joad family as they leave Oklahoma during the Great Depression and head west to California in search of a better life. The novel highlights the struggles of migrant workers and critiques social inequality.

29.title: The Silence of the Lambs
29.author: Thomas Harris
29.description: FBI agent Clarice Starling seeks the help of imprisoned cannibalistic serial killer Hannibal Lecter to catch another serial killer on the loose. The novel is a chilling exploration of human depravity and psychological manipulation.

30.title: The Hunger Games
30.author: Suzanne Collins
30.description: Set in a future dystopian society, Katniss Everdeen is thrust into a brutal televised competition where children fight to the death. The novel critiques the exploitation of reality television and explores themes of survival, rebellion, and sacrifice.

31.title: The Fault in Our Stars
31.author: John Green
31.description: Hazel Grace Lancaster, a teenage cancer patient, falls in love with Augustus Waters, a cancer survivor. Together, they navigate the challenges of illness, love, and mortality in this emotional and heart-wrenching novel.

32.title: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe
32.author: C.S. Lewis
32.description: Four siblings are transported to the magical land of Narnia through an old wardrobe, where they join forces with Aslan the lion to fight against the White Witch and bring peace to the land.

33.title: The Catcher in the Rye
33.author: J.D. Salinger
33.description: Holden Caulfield, a disillusioned teenager, narrates his experiences after being expelled from an elite prep school. He grapples with depression, alienation, and the loss of innocence.

34.title: The Hobbit
34.author: J.R.R. Tolkien
34.description: Bilbo Baggins, a hobbit, embarks on a perilous journey with a group of dwarves to reclaim their home from the dragon Smaug. Along the way, he encounters trolls, goblins, and elves, while discovering his own bravery.

35.title: The Outsiders
35.author: S.E. Hinton
35.description: The Outsiders tells the story of two rival teenage gangs, the Greasers and the Socs, and the struggles they face in a divided society. It explores themes of friendship, identity, and social inequality.

36.title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo
36.author: Stieg Larsson
36.description: Journalist Mikael Blomkvist teams up with the mysterious and brilliant hacker Lisbeth Salander to investigate the disappearance of a young woman from a powerful family. The investigation uncovers dark secrets and dangers.

37.title: The Martian
37.author: Andy Weir
37.description: Astronaut Mark Watney is stranded on Mars after a mission goes awry. Using his knowledge of science, he must find a way to survive while trying to communicate with NASA back on Earth.

38.title: The Handmaid's Tale
38.author: Margaret Atwood
38.description: In a totalitarian society, women’s rights have been stripped away. Offred, a woman forced into reproductive servitude, struggles to maintain her humanity while defying the oppressive regime.

39.title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian
39.author: C.S. Lewis
39.description: The Pevensie siblings return to Narnia to find it under the rule of the evil Telmarines. They join forces with Prince Caspian to restore Narnia's rightful king and defeat the usurpers.

40.title: Slaughterhouse-Five
40.author: Kurt Vonnegut
40.description: Billy Pilgrim, a soldier who survives the bombing of Dresden, becomes 'unstuck in time,' experiencing events of his life out of sequence. Vonnegut's novel is a satirical commentary on the absurdities of war.

41.title: Brave New World
41.author: Aldous Huxley
41.description: In a world dominated by technology, genetic engineering, and a rigid caste system, individuals are conditioned to conform. Bernard Marx, a discontented citizen, begins questioning the nature of this seemingly perfect society.

42.title: Wuthering Heights
42.author: Emily Brontë
42.description: The novel tells the tragic love story of Heathcliff and Catherine Earnshaw, whose obsessive and destructive passion leads to pain and revenge across generations.

43.title: The Great Gatsby
43.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
43.description: Set in the Jazz Age, the novel follows Jay Gatsby's obsessive pursuit of the elusive Daisy Buchanan. It critiques the excesses of wealth and explores themes of love, class, and the American Dream.

44.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
44.author: Oscar Wilde
44.description: Dorian Gray, a handsome young man, remains eternally youthful while his portrait ages, reflecting the moral decay of his character. Wilde critiques vanity and the pursuit of beauty at all costs.

45.title: The Poisonwood Bible
45.author: Barbara Kingsolver
45.description: The Price family moves to the Congo in 1959, where father Nathan, a missionary, seeks to convert the locals. His rigid, domineering ways lead to tragedy for his family, as they struggle to survive and adapt to their new surroundings.

46.title: The Secret History
46.author: Donna Tartt
46.description: A group of elite college students commit a murder that sets off a series of tragic events. The novel delves into themes of guilt, beauty, and intellectualism, set against a hauntingly atmospheric backdrop.

47.title: The Kite Runner
47.author: Khaled Hosseini
47.description: In a story of betrayal and redemption, Amir, a young boy from Kabul, struggles to come to terms with his past, particularly his failure to protect his childhood friend Hassan.

48.title: The Road
48.author: Cormac McCarthy
48.description: A father and son journey through a bleak, desolate America following an unspecified catastrophe. As they struggle to survive, they find hope and love in each other amidst the dire circumstances.

49.title: The Hunger Games
49.author: Suzanne Collins
49.description: Katniss Everdeen enters a deadly televised competition where children fight for survival. The book critiques the spectacle of violence, the cost of rebellion, and the exploitation of the powerless.

50.title: The Shining
50.author: Stephen King
50.description: Jack Torrance, a struggling writer, accepts a position as the winter caretaker of the Overlook Hotel, where he gradually loses his sanity due to the supernatural forces haunting the hotel.

51.title: The Art of War
51.author: Sun Tzu
51.description: An ancient Chinese text on military strategy and tactics, The Art of War has been applied to various fields, including leadership, business, and personal development.

52.title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
52.author: Gabriel García Márquez
52.description: A multi-generational tale of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo, this novel blends the fantastical and the real, exploring themes of solitude, love, and fate.

53.title: The Girl on the Train
53.author: Paula Hawkins
53.description: Rachel, an alcoholic woman, becomes obsessed with a couple she watches from the train each day. When the woman goes missing, Rachel is drawn into the investigation, leading to twists and revelations.

54.title: The Giver
54.author: Lois Lowry
54.description: In a society where emotions and choices are controlled, Jonas, a young boy, is selected to receive memories of the past. He soon learns the truth about his society and the cost of living without freedom.

55.title: The Maze Runner
55.author: James Dashner
55.description: Thomas wakes up in a maze with no memory of his past. Along with other 'Gladers,' he must find a way to escape, discovering dark secrets and conspiracies behind the maze's existence.

56.title: The Catcher in the Rye
56.author: J.D. Salinger
56.description: Holden Caulfield, a disenchanted teenager, narrates his time wandering New York City after being expelled from his prep school, exploring themes of alienation, innocence, and loss.

57.title: The Bell Jar
57.author: Sylvia Plath
57.description: The semi-autobiographical novel follows Esther Greenwood, a young woman who struggles with mental illness, reflecting on the pressures of societal expectations and the loss of identity.

58.title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire
58.author: Suzanne Collins
58.description: The second book in the series follows Katniss Everdeen as she becomes the face of rebellion in a dystopian world, participating in a new deadly Hunger Games to defy the oppressive Capitol.

59.title: Shantaram
59.author: Gregory David Roberts
59.description: An Australian fugitive escapes to Bombay, where he gets entangled in the city's underworld. This epic novel blends action, romance, and philosophy in the backdrop of a vibrant city.

60.title: The Time Traveler's Wife
60.author: Audrey Niffenegger
60.description: Henry DeTamble involuntarily time travels, causing a strain on his relationship with Clare Abshire. Their love story spans across time, exploring fate, loss, and the passage of time.

61.title: The Road
61.author: Cormac McCarthy
61.description: A father and his son navigate a desolate America after an unspecified disaster, struggling for survival in a bleak world. Despite the bleak setting, their bond offers a glimpse of hope.

62.title: Pride and Prejudice
62.author: Jane Austen
62.description: Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy navigate the complexities of love, family, and social expectations in early 19th-century England. Austen's wit and critique of societal norms shine through in this beloved classic.

63.title: Murder on the Orient Express
63.author: Agatha Christie
63.description: Hercule Poirot, the famous detective, investigates a murder aboard the luxurious Orient Express. The twists and turns in the plot make it one of Christie's most celebrated works.

64.title: Dune
64.author: Frank Herbert
64.description: Set on the desert planet Arrakis, the novel follows Paul Atreides as he navigates political intrigue and the control of the valuable spice melange, which is key to the survival of the galaxy.

65.title: The Alchemist
65.author: Paulo Coelho
65.description: Santiago, a shepherd, sets off on a journey to find a treasure, discovering profound truths about life, destiny, and the importance of following one's dreams.

66.title: Gone with the Wind
66.author: Margaret Mitchell
66.description: Scarlett O'Hara navigates life and love during the Civil War and Reconstruction era. Her struggles with passion, survival, and pride make this a sweeping American classic.

67.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
67.author: Oscar Wilde
67.description: Dorian Gray makes a wish to remain youthful forever, while his portrait bears the toll of his decadent and corrupt life. Wilde's novel explores beauty, morality, and the consequences of vanity.

68.title: The Devil in the White City
68.author: Erik Larson
68.description: This gripping true crime narrative intertwines the story of the 1893 Chicago World's Fair with that of H.H. Holmes, one of America's first serial killers, highlighting the dark side of American progress.

69.title: A Song of Ice and Fire: A Game of Thrones
69.author: George R.R. Martin
69.description: Noble families fight for control of the Iron Throne in the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros, amidst political intrigue, betrayal, and the looming threat of winter and dragons.

70.title: The Giver
70.author: Lois Lowry
70.description: Jonas lives in a world where emotions and memories are controlled. As he begins to receive memories of the past, he learns the dark truths about his society and his own potential.

71.title: The Outsiders
71.author: S.E. Hinton
71.description: A story about the rivalry between two groups of teens, the Greasers and the Socs. The novel deals with themes of social class, loyalty, and the struggles of adolescence.

72.title: The Maze Runner
72.author: James Dashner
72.description: Thomas wakes up in a maze with no memory and joins other kids trying to escape. The story explores themes of survival, trust, and the mysteries of the world outside.

73.title: Life of Pi
73.author: Yann Martel
73.description: Pi Patel survives a shipwreck and is left stranded on a lifeboat in the Pacific Ocean with a Bengal tiger. The novel examines faith, survival, and the power of storytelling.

74.title: The Shining
74.author: Stephen King
74.description: Jack Torrance and his family take a job at the isolated Overlook Hotel, where Jack slowly loses his sanity, influenced by supernatural forces. This chilling novel is one of King's best.

75.title: The Secret History
75.author: Donna Tartt
75.description: A group of elite college students commits a murder, unraveling a web of secrets, betrayal, and tragedy. This novel is a dark exploration of youth, power, and guilt.

76.title: Brave New World
76.author: Aldous Huxley
76.description: In a highly controlled society, citizens are kept in line through pleasure, drugs, and conditioning. The novel critiques modern consumerism and the loss of individuality.

77.title: Fahrenheit 451
77.author: Ray Bradbury
77.description: In a future society where books are banned and 'firemen' burn them, Guy Montag begins to question the oppressive system that controls information and the meaning of life.

78.title: Norwegian Wood
78.author: Haruki Murakami
78.description: Set in 1960s Tokyo, this novel explores love, loss, and mental health as Toru Watanabe navigates the complexities of his relationships with two women.

79.title: The Sun Also Rises
79.author: Ernest Hemingway
79.description: A group of expatriates in post-World War I Europe struggle with feelings of disillusionment, searching for meaning in their lives amidst the hedonistic atmosphere of the Lost Generation.

80.title: The Fault in Our Stars
80.author: John Green
80.description: Hazel Grace Lancaster and Augustus Waters fall in love while battling cancer, sharing their fears, hopes, and a deep connection that transcends their illnesses.
